audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker welcoming listeners to Nuke Berlin, indicating that he is with Dialexion. He inquires about the band's status around 2018. Another male speaker responds positively, noting that they have a new lineup formed about a year ago as a three-piece. He says they've got a new guitar player and expresses satisfaction with how things are coming together, noting that this tour is the first full tour and explains the other shows they've done recently. The speaker's tone is conversational and somewhat informal. He admits that the start was shaky but thinks that they're getting into their stride. Finally, the first speaker then replies with an "okay". A low musical thrum drones underneath all of the speech.

The audio begins with a male speaker talking about a tour and his expectations, referencing previous locations and emphasizing his excitement to play for European audiences. He expresses a particular interest in performing in Italy, France, and similar regions, where he feels his style is well-received. He then asserts the importance of live gigs for him, stressing the band's selectivity about venues and their appreciation for playing to the right crowds. Transitioning to music, a generic pop-song plays briefly in the background. The audio then shifts back to the male speaker, who initiates a new topic related to the music.

The audio clip features one male speaker discussing his sources of inspiration for his music and lyrics. He speaks in a conversational tone, mentioning old-school death metal bands such as "Sacrofago, Blasphemy, Creator, Destruction", and newer bands like "Conqueror". He emphasizes the importance of hateful and aggressive lyrics with powerful action words in old-school phrasing. In the background, there's the sound of music, presumably death metal, providing an ambient layer to the interview.

The audio clip begins with speech from what appears to be an interview setting. The speaker, presumably a band member, speaks dismissively about genre labels like death metal or black metal, stating they "don't really give a shit." A second interviewer speaker prompts a response on the importance of genres, to which the first speaker elaborates, suggesting that the significance of these terms has diminished over time. He mentions a shift to smaller, more interconnected scenes, diminishing the importance of labels. Finally, the second interviewer notes the band's long journey in metal music. All this is punctuated by the sounds of heavy metal music playing intermittently in the background.

The audio features one speaker with a casual tone, who claims not to be the right person to ask and mentions being with "these guys" for a year. It starts with a question, "So, what have been the most memorable moments for you?" followed by the speaker's reply, "Well, for me, I'm not the right person to ask." He adds, "If I was to talk about this man for me."

The audio clip features a conversation with one male speaker who expresses enthusiasm about a band's experiences, including a California deathfest and getting back to touring. He mentions the band regrouping and testing out their new lineup. He emphasizes the importance of current steps they're taking. The speech then shifts to discussing personal musical career experiences, contrasting best and worst moments. During the speech, there are audible background sounds suggesting an active environment, possibly a live music venue or event, adding an ambient layer to the recording.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing his previous band, mentioning "cool stuff" and being "the first metal band" from New Zealand to tour Europe and America, conveying a tone of pride. He then discusses playing with "heroes" like Slayer and touring Europe with Amon Amarth and Kreator, suggesting touring is the "most important thing about music." The speaker considers albums secondary, preferring the "live stuff."

The clip features a male speaker, who mentions an album released in 2014 called "Cassandrian".  He then asks if there is any idea when new music will be heard. The speaker is using a conversational tone.

The clip starts with a male voice discussing plans for next year, mentioning having a label, a deal, and an album in progress, with the majority of the album written and recording planned for sometime between now and December. He mentions the album should be out early next year. Then, a second male voice asks about the music, inquiring what kind of music they will hear. The first male voice responds by characterizing the music as simpler, rawer, and more like Doom Cults or War of Attrition. The speaker indicates that the band feels that going with a simpler, more primitive, and old-school sound is their goal. Overall, they want to move back in a more primitive direction. The clip ends with the sounds of an engine starting.

The audio begins with a male speaker introducing a topic, stating "as it happens, there has actually been" several New Zealand metal bands visiting Berlin this summer, mentioning that they have already interviewed a couple. The speaker then asks a question about the New Zealand metal scene. This speech transitions to an indiscernible statement, perhaps the beginning of a response, and then fades out. Throughout the audio, background noise with a rhythmic and consistent quality can be heard, suggesting the sounds of a moving vehicle, likely a car, indicative of an outdoor setting.

The audio clip starts with what sounds like an intake of breath, followed by a male speaker who answers a question candidly, noting that the subject of the question, presumably something local, has "died out". He doesn't have too many good things to say, except for some band recommendations such as, "Harussiak, I really like them, through different styles, but colonel". He also mentions the existence of many up-and-coming bands, but says, "It's lost a little bit of what it used to have" and finishes with "That's about all I have to say". The speech is briefly followed by laughter.

The audio clip features one male speaker discussing how the New Zealand metal scene used to be better, describing it as more vibrant and with more people attending. He notes a decline in venues and local scene activity, suggesting a "lull patch". Background noise is present, but indistinct.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker who believes certain things are happening where the infrastructure and business side of music have been depleted, making it difficult for things to work. His tone is conversational and analytical. He continues, stating that it makes it hard to make things work and that infrastructure is what makes everything tick, implying it's an effect of life. Another male speaker then thanks him, wishing him "break a leg tonight" with a slightly formal tone.

The clip begins with two male speakers, one expressing "No problem, thanks a lot man, cheers, appreciate it." The other responds simply with "Thank you." The clip then transitions into a sound, possibly a whoosh, or movement of air, suggesting a change in environment or action.
